Oh, it'll work. It'll be reliable. SpaceX will use it for a moon landing (if NASA coughs up the dough for the mission costs). But the big question is: what is it actually for ? The one good thing about NASA is that their human space missions always had technology built around clearly defined objectives: get humans into LEO, get them to stay up there for long periods of time, get them to the moon for a brief visit. All PR work to prove to Americans and their allies that America was the greatest country on Earth. Within its parameters the strategy worked.

So what is Starship for? First off, it's no use for getting to any star. That would require a massive generation ship and thousands of years. It's also no use for long deep space missions as it has no shielding against Cosmic radiation. The shielding would add hundreds of additional tons of mass to the ship making it impossible to launch, never mind land.

And what's the market for deep space missions anyway? SpaceX makes its money putting telecommunications satellites into orbit and subcontracting for NASA. That's it. There's no viable market for getting a relatively large amount of humans into space (a couple of dozen as opposed to two or three), and there is no way the combined economic infrastructure of planet Earth could create and sustain a Mars colony if that's what Elon Musk has in mind. The cost would be unthinkable. A single manned mission there, for a short visit, hovers around the one trillion dollar mark.

I suspect Starship is a glamorous, media-friendly white elephant, just as the Shuttle was. Prove me wrong.

The flip should occur somewhere between the 2.5 km and 550 m you mentioned. Maybe 1.5 km. That could mean 400 m/s DeltaV or a difference of ~10 t of propellant. With the plan to refuel them at ~100 t at a time in LEO anyway, it is not a biggie. And it buys a lot of reliability/safety. Very little doubt in my mind that it should be in that range. But yes, I agree, bellyflop is a good idea compared propulsive landing. Similar to SS orbiter reentry (~40 deg alpha), only better. Reentry from say DearMoon may still be at 40 deg but will increase to 90 in denser atm. DearMoon will not refuel but their payload is also not 100 t.

Whilst out by a factor of around 100 the Cirrus Airframe Parachute System (or CAPS) is installed not only on the smaller single engine piston aircraft they make, but also the Vision Jet with a maximum weight of 2722kg has an airframe parachute that catches the entire aircraft in an engine failure situation (as it's a single engine aircraft). To shorten the deployment cycle the parachute is extracted by a small rocket motor that for the piston aircraft means it can catch the aircraft in level flight at 600ft above the ground.

I love your work and I liked this video specially because you addressed the approach of horizontal landing which is the best way for getting a stable position after touching down. I'd like you analise some day the possibility of adding a final maneuver the following way:
1) Touch down vertical on 2 legs (rear fins?)
2) immediately (or simultaneously) flip to horizontal with the gas thrusters resting finally horizontal on the rear legs and 1 or 2 legs placed near the nose (perhaps the nose fins?).
Inverse maneuver for lift off:
1) flip to vertical with nose thrusters.
2) normal lift off
With this adicional maneuver you don't need to worry so much about wind on Earth or irregularities like boulders or differential load capacity under the legs for first landings on other celestial bodies
The great problem that I see with Starship is that is more a rocket than a ship. At least for first landings you need a pad on the Moon or Mars and something to deal with winds on Earth. The starship is too light and has a too hight center of mass.
Perhaps an integrated bow to stern girder is needed or gas pressure can be enought to stiffen the ship in order to rest horizontal.
It would be cool if you could explore this approach.

My family moved to Melbourne Fl. in 1961 because my Army Capitan father was stationed to Patrick AFB to help develop the Pershing ballistic missile for the Army at Cape Canaveral launch facility. I was 11 at that time.
I left for college at 18 in August of 1969. In the years between arriving and going to college I witnessed MANY a successful and unsuccessful rocket launching. Including the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo missions.
Successes and failures are ALWAYS a part of space exploration. Just as air flight was and automotive development was too.
Even with the Best Scientists and Engineers and Technicians that $$$$ could buy. Remember every part of those machines were purchased by the lowest bid. As I’m sure SpaceX does also.
My father told me, “Son, no adventure involving Great distance, Speedy travel and Difficult conditions will be successful, without Cost, Danger and Death unless you are Very smart, Very careful, Very determined and Very prepared for failure and success.”
Smart man my father!

I don’t know why SpaceX doesn’t do its belly flop like it does now but rather than a propulsive flip, why not start a little earlier and use flaps and rcs or hot gas thrusters to get the starship vertical and once vertical, start the raptors. That way you eliminate the sloshing, fuel will be at the feed lines so no cold starts and engine explosions. Also no crazy propulsive flip that will have passengers upchucking. This way it’s more gradual and when the raptors fire the passengers would be facing up in the best position to absorb the G-forces. It will cause the starship to speed up more before the raptors start but there’s more than sufficient power to land easily. Also easier to catch cause it’s not rocking and correcting and rocking some more.

I remember reading during the early space program there was a demonstration of orbital mechanics using army jeeps moving in circle at a constant velocity at different diameters. This showed the energy gains and losses moving to higher or lower orbits that were necessary to achieve docking of two craft in orbit. I found this very easy to visualise ie slowing down decreases altitude which means faster orbit. I hope I have that right. Using the vehicle as a demo was very good and I use this when passing, in anticipating a passing point approaching  , I back off a distance then accelerate as the point approaches so at the passing point my velocity is a fair bit greater than the vehicle to be passed. This gives a shorter distance to pass and it is far easier to shed energy if the passing manoeuvre  has to be abandoned. If you have a low powered car this makes passing easy.

I'm not sold on the belly flop method and I doubt they will ever be man-rated.  I suspect they will have to use the Space Shuttle method of a glider landing.  To do a glider landing the craft would need the wings typical of a lifting body and it would need landing gear and maybe parachutes.  That would add mass, but the winglets and landing gear with the current design have mass as does the propellent needed for the landing burn with the required safety margins.  Then, which approach would be more reliable -- a glider landing or a propulsive landing.  On this final point the flawed Shuttle never had a crash caused by failure of the lifting body hardware and energy management software -- the Columbia incident was caused by foam hitting the leading edge during launch and putting a future space plane on top with nothing to hit it would remove that risk entirely.

Nice explanation (as usual)!
One thing I find interesting and disappointing at the same time is how many times I hear "SpaceX crashed another one of their rockets".
SpaceX has been in development of the Starship (/Starhopper) for about 9 years and in that time has had 8 "successful" launches, tons of static firings and 4-6 "successful" "landings" depending on what you call a "successful landing". I has been a huge success and they have made amazing progress and done many things others though were impossible.
On the other hand, SLS has been in development singe 2005 (as Constellation) (16 years) with some components dating back to the 1970's. So far it has one successful static firing, no launches, and it will never land (by any definition). IMHO, that is not a lot of progress for for 16 years of work and billions of dollars.
SpaceX could taken the politically easy path of launching a Starship to orbit years ago, but getting to orbit is not the hard part. They are doing the smart thing and working on the most difficult part first. This way they don't end up throwing away effort on a design that would have to change. Just like the Wright Brothers, SpaceX is not focused on flying (which the Wright Brothers were not the first to do). They, as the Wright Brothers did, are focusing instead on landing safely. Sounds like a good plan to me.

if the header tanks have about 30 tons of total fuel, by my best calculations SN10 had roughly 5 tons of fuel left on board at landing. It burned 3 engines for 7 seconds then reduced down to 1 engine for about 17 seconds. The raptor burns about .667 tons of fuel per seconds so 3 engines burning at once burns 2 tons per seconds. for 7 seconds of a 3 engine burn costs 14 tons of fuel, then for 17 seconds on a single engine costs 11.3 tons. some of the burn was likely not at full throttle so we can safely assume that the only Starship to land had more than 5 tons of fuel in it's header tanks after landing. There may have also been a fair bit of fuel in the main tanks too.

Viewed in perspective, Starship's landing system is not that crazy after all.

The thinner atmosphere results in less aerodynamic drag, up to a point where the terminal velocity is faster than on earth, despite the reduced gravity. But that reduced gravity results in a much higher thrust-to-weight ratio for the engine. As per the video one raptor at 40% has a less than 1 T-to-W ratio which is ok, it'll just throttle a litte bit up to slow down and stop at the right spot, but on Mars that T-to-W ratio is much higher, close to 2 maybe. At the end of the runway is a launch and landing tower for Superheavy. Superheavy comes down vertically and is caught by the tower and ready to launch again as soon as it is fueled. Starship lands at a runway and remains horizontal. Mostly works like a glider ala space shuttle but Starship will have enough fuel for runway go-around capability. Then it taxis to the launch tower and cranes flip it vertical and put it on the Superheavy.

On Mars a spaceplane glider landing like the space shuttle should work fine. On the Moon obviously you remain vertical the entire time.

The comparison with a car braking near a stop sign is way, way too generic and imprecise to be of any use. When stopping your car you can decide to go from a nice, slow 0.1g deceleration to a 1 g deceleration any time you want, because something happened or just because you wanted. You can stop ten meters before the stop, and then stay there for an hour, for no reason at all. You have no problem at all with winds of even tropical storm force. And if you misjudge the stopping and end up at a standstill 20 meters from the stop, you just press the accelerator a few millimeters and the car will gracefully move to the stop sign at almost no speed at all. In almost any of the cases above, in a hovering rocket you are dead, D-E-D. dead.

Thoughts for a crewed Starship:  Put a crew capsule at the very top, just big enough to fit all the humans and 10 minutes of life support for them.  Ride the belly flop down to a couple km of altitude at 150m/s terminal velocity. Then while still in the belly flop separate the crew capsule and land it with parachutes.  Ideally the crew capsule will be only 5% or so of the total dry weight and can be landed with 100% reliability using modest parachutes, especially since it will separate from the main Starship at only about 150m/s.  The main part of the vehicle lands using the low-altitude flip maneuver.  Since there are no humans in the main part, a 90% or 95% success rate would be totally acceptable.  Biggest risk factor I can think of is that the crew capsule needs to achieve enough horizontal separation from the main vehicle that crew will be safe even if the main vehicle crashes and explodes.

I'm pretty sure you could even survive a Starship crash when all engines fail. That's a 50m tall crush core. Assuming a crash speed of 300 kph (83 m/s) that's merely 6-8 G's of negative acceleration sustained for 1 second or so. Humans survived 40 G's for a second in ground tests. So it would be a matter of designing the booster so that it releases pressure and folds in the right way. There would be a fireball but the people were pretty safe from that. Another option is to simply land over water to completely get rid of the fire problem. As long as you keep some air bubble intact where the pessengers sit it wouldn't sink. All you had to make sure is that the booster flips before touch down even if the engines fail.

The ney-sayers need to examine the history of SpaceX. There were 13 failed landing attempts for Falcon-9 before they got it 100% perfect. Seven of those were "learning" on the v1.0 and v1.1 boosters, after they got it to work - three more failures were with v1.2 (aka block 4). The three "failures" with the present block 5 design were all cases where they had "stretched" the fuel requirements and knew up-front that they might not get a good landing. So essentially, block 5 is flawless.But it took seven attempts with seven failures before they nailed it... So seeing just four 12km test failures of StarShip is *FAR* from surprising. If history repeats itself, then we should expect three more total failures before they get it right just once - and we should expect several failures after that in the name of reliability.

Yo, this braking exercise you did is also called “trail braking” in the racing world. The best racers can brake late and keep the tires on the limit of grip. As the race goes on, they have to brake sooner every lap because their tires get worn. They also burn fuel, so the limit of grip is an invisible line that requires experience to feel.

The Problem is, there is no failure system, if something goes wrong with the raptors at landing or reignition, you're flat as a pancake.
Nearly all vital systems, regardless of the field have a second system, often even with completly different methods of operation.
(present safty systems on maned rockets, ejector seats in fighter jets, second avionik systems in airplains,, air system in submarens, etc..)

Therfore the only option is to integrate such system (why not a 3. stage for maned mmissons with a completly diffrent starship-top)
Or you have to be so reliable that you could work with no safty system, the problem is, how reliable would be enough ?
Normally if a failure is lethal to many people or maassive enviromental damage would happen,
the probability of default has to be lower than 10^-9 if it only concerns a few people the probability it is lower than 10^-7
The qustion is if this could be reliably verified with such a low operating time of the engines.
Over time probably but, if you change a few things, (which spaceX does a lot), you would have to verify it again...

Of course there are systems that have at some points no second system, for example a airplane turbines.
At the runway is a point, where the plane is to fast to brake, so it has to take up. At that point the engine shouldn't fail, since you could not emergeny land with no height. This is also true for small planes with only one motor
But in relation to the operating time of turbines, this timeframe is so low, that the failure probability is lower than 10^-9 (or 10^-7).
The probability can be verifiyed by the millions of operating hours of all turbines all around teh world.
For rocket engines this would be a lot harder.

Anyways we will see what they come up with :)

Well my semi educated response is to get max aerodynamic braking.

1. If it takes 200 meters to flip and start the engines then that’s the height, plus whatever altitude it takes to slow to landing speed. That gives you a number so that’s the number. Assign more gives you nothing except more propellant mass required = more aerodynamic braking required or even more propellant required = more delta V / propellant required to leave earth LEO for Mars = more propellant loadings in earth LEO ~ Tank volume may be an issue so less payload to Mars to account for increased propellant requirements.

2. There is basically just enough atmosphere to destroy a space craft but not that much for aero braking. Aero braking require an air MASS and density to push against. There is more of that near the ground so aero braking for as long as possible take advantage of the best part of the atmosphere available. Not only is the atmosphere way denser near the surface making aero braking vastly more efficient let’s say 20 times as just a number, but since you’re going so much slower under 500 kmh as opposed to 50 000 kmh it means you get to take advantage of it for 100 times as long. This means with these example numbers, you get 2000 times the braking per unit distance flown down real low compared to the same distance flown up high.

2.5 well SpaceX has always said it needed and intended to choose near equator and lowest altitude landing sites available for many reasons. Well this is probably one of them. So at night in winter landing will increase surface pressures by 50%over a summer day landing time.

3. If the flip to land works then it works. If it doesn’t then it doesn’t. So far it does. Failures are so far, plumbing, ignition timing and engine reliability issues. But the thing can flip and flip back without breaking up, so the flip works. Now the rest of it, lucky this is a TEST program and not the production model duels program. So calculate the height and do it.

The "last minute" aspect of the flip isn't as scary if you know how landing an airplane is done. Every time that airliner you're riding is on final approach, it's descending at about 15-20 miles an hour until you're literally over the end of the runway. Then, at the "last second," the pilots bring the nose up to flatten out the descent until you touch down while descending at 2-3 miles per hour. If they don't, at best, you'll wonder if you've permanently compressed your spine from that landing... and at worst, Important Things break.

Any time you're landing any vehicle, there's some fancy moves involved at the last second to make a smooth, safe, and efficient landing...

Great vid! I love it. You should do a video about ground effect. In order to successfully land one of these things, the hardest problem engineers have to solve is the physics of ground-effect. Ground effect (amplified by a nearly 10 foot wall around the landing area) is what caused the first helicopter to crash during the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. Ground effect is a well known but poorly understood/studied physical phenomenon that has major implications in aviation (both for fixed-wing, but primarily rotorcraft operation) and HUGE implications for propulsively landing a rocket.

The Rocketdyne F-1 engine on the Saturn V flew 65 times in 13 launches with 100% reliability. The Space Shuttle Main Engine flew on the 133 Shuttle flights that landed successfully with only one engine failure for 398/399= 99.75% reliability. The Merlin 1D engine has flown on at least 100 Falcon 9 launches with 1 engine failure. That's 899/900=99.89% reliability.

Those are the performance numbers that Raptor has to achieve to land Starship with humans onboard safely. Right now Starship has made four launches with 12 engines and 2 engine failures, which is 10/12=83.33% reliability.

Elon has a huge mountain to climb before the Raptor is ready for prime time. Even if there is only one Raptor failure in the next ten Starship prototype launches, the reliability would only be 29/30=96.67%. NASA is going to expect a lot better Raptor reliability before launching the second HLS demo flight to the lunar surface with humans onboard. Once Raptor engine reliability is 99% or better, the altitude at which the flip is done becomes less of an issue.

Bear in mind that, although we’re starting to see SpaceX launch Starship prototypes now from the ground, Starship is a second-stage vehicle!

As Tim mentioned briefly at time ~11:20, the big difference between Starship landing and a Falcon 9 booster landing is that an expended second stage travels vastly faster than an expended first stage! To reserve enough fuel to propulsively land a second stage vehicle would require an enormous amount of extra fuel weight!

Now these Starship prototypes of course aren’t flying that fast in these early tests, but in their future, final usage, the amount of kinetic energy they will have to bleed off is enormous!

They should use giant blimps tethered to the ground near the landing pad that go up thousands of meters in the air and have a cable system strung between them. Then the starship could release a cable with a hook on its way down during freefall, snag the cable, and the buoyancy of the blimps would slow down the starship gradually, pulling them down, and eventually stop before hitting the ground. Then you would simply reel in the blimps to get the starship safely to the ground. This would obviate the need for restarting the engine, keeping fuel onboard after orbit, and having beefy landing struts. It would also make for some primo ad space on the blimps.

I found out, parachutes can be used as a means to increase the safety of Starship, at least in KSP. By using only a small drogue chute mounted on the nose that isn't enough to slow down the vessel to a safe landing speed, but more than enough to pull the vessel up straight. Even if the Starship lost control and tumbling through the air,  After deployment at 2000 meters, it will slow down the vessel to a measly 20m/s, saving over 200m/s of delta-V compared to a full propulsive landing. The final landing burn is done with a single engine, giving enough margin of error for even manual control.

The results speak for themselves,  what is the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) Inspector going to say in his report! This is a terrible, bottom of the barrel , down right dangerous product. If I were a space tourist I would opt for a landing mode that has a much more resilient failure mode. The mere suggestion that humans use this extreme cost-cut and dangerous landing mode is plainly fatuous and is the very essence of a solution seeking a problem.  That said, if the idea is for unmanned cargo delivery then SpaceX is best served by stating that intention at the soonest opportunity. All the talk of potential human use of this mode sounds completely disingenuous and potentially serves to obfuscate the true aims of the company's choice of this landing maneuver. As informative and fascinating as this video was, it is the information that was left out that concerns me the most. The results speak for themselves any failure, no matter how small, results in immediate, irrecoverable catastrophe.  If SpaceX really do plan to land humans with this maneuver then it is only a matter of time before bereaved loved ones call the NTSB.

Any ship in freefall is subject to freefall rate of 7 MPS. The ship goes faster to liftoff. So when the ship  {Controlled flipped } it still will be subject to switching to freefall when it has been made upright unless to burn takes it back up above to the lift allowance. At the upright position the ship needs an acceleration rate that is again equal to original liftoff speed for a fraction shorter timeframe to counteract gravity & side burns to avoid side falling. Because of the exaggerated weight of the ship it needs a much higher altitude to reach the extra lift to reach dynamic lift & hold so de acceleration can commence. To make my point more simple!. A helicopter on decent has commenced accelerating & not decelerating which is why the rotors bent upward under the effect of gravity & wind resistance. The same for Starship. The initial fuel weight before liftoff would need to be increased to allow for a extra hard burn of more fuel to bring an equilibrium @ vertical level before the slowing of the fuel burn rate which allows for decent @ almost an instance equal to the same. When Mars comes to mind the dynamics completely are changed. You speak of wasting fuel & Gravity. Fuel efficiency usage will help make the project work. There always will be some efficiency loss at some point.

OK, darn I hate to do this again, but another nit picky physics comment: You said if you have 1000 N of thrust on a 1000 N rocket then "you would hover." Not necessarily true. You got it right a few seconds later when you said that acceleration would be zero. But zero acceleration does not mean zero velocity. Zero acceleration only means constant velocity. You also got it right later when you said, "just means your velocity is not changing." AND . . . you also said that if your thrust to weight ratio is 0.9:1 then "you will go down." Also not necessarily true. Your acceleration will be in the downward direction, but that doesn't mean you velocity also has be be down. You can be going up with a downward acceleration--you'll just be slowing down. Like I said, just being nit picky. Overall I think you did a good job with the thrust:weight part of the video.

Nit picky physics comment here: You said, "the more drag an object has, the slower its terminal velocity."  That's not quite right.  I mean it gets the spirit right, but it's a bit more complicated.  And obviously too complicated for this video. To put it shortly, the velocity of a falling object will be determined in part by its drag.  The drag is also determined in part by the velocity.  So they affect each other.  It turns into a differential equation.  The  result is that the terminal velocity is the end result of drag and velocity competing against each other.

Starship is having issues with gas (He) mixing into the fuel.  Causing failure in the rocket engines. Until they resolve the fuel flow in +/- 4gs they're going to keep crashing their rockets. Tim, you are way too scared of the 'belly flop'. Every single thing in a rocket is equally scary.. if engines fail during takeoff, or any other point, the outcome is not much better. Yes, there is redundancy sometimes .. but very little. The 'stopping calculation' is just a simple one; not any harder than calculating orbital burns, and significantly simpler than hitting the correct Moon orbit. Perhaps it looks intuitively scary (because we are poor judges of how scary orbital insertion is) but what matters is reliability. Every day, billions of people put their trust in a simple device called 'a brake' which if it fails,  has exactly the same consequences as a Raptor not working during landing. Yes, a brake can be made very reliable, but we are talking hundreds of billions of braking events per day vs a single event of landing a starship. Yes, we got used to people dying because of brake failures, but that is just a matter of media attention. When rockets are more commonplace, an accident will be more like an aeroplane accident these days; it wont stop all flights for a decade anymore. How reliable is reliable enough? it's all a matter of PR impact. Car and aeroplane companies know all about it. it's cruel but it's the way the universe works. Nothing is 100% reliable; this is actually a law of nature.

THRUST-TO-WEIGHT RATIO: Both "weight" and "thrust" are directional (vector) values. When Starship is descending belly-first, the weight direction from gravity is vertically downward. Then when lighting the Raptor engines while Starship is horizontal, they will have a thrust direction horizontal, which is 90 degrees to the weight direction. The thrust-to-weight ratio would therefore be 0:1, since none of the thrust is pushing against gravity. While Starship is horizontal, lighting either one Raptor engine or three engines, the thrust-to-weight ratio is still 0:1 because none of the thrust is pushing upward. As Starship rotates to vertical, the vertical component of thrust is slowly increasing proportional to the trigonometric sine of Starships angle from horizontal, which gives time to test the Raptor engines and decide which engine or engines to use, before having any significant thrust-to-weight ratio. When Raptor engines are gimbaled upward to rotate the Starship from horizontal to vertical, the thrust-to-weight ratio will be a slight negative value for a few seconds, so that a small percentage of Raptor engine thrust will accelerate the Starship downward.

POUNDS: At 14:14 referring to Imperial/British/English units of pounds, the quote is "Of course, it would be just as easy to use pounds and pounds-force in this example, ...". Technically "pounds" and "pounds-force" are from different variations of the Foot-Pound-Second system. The three main variations of the Foot-Pound-Second system are:

British Gravitational (BG)
pound : force
slug : mass
Absolute English (AE)
poundal : force
pound : mass
English Engineering (EE)
pound-force : force
pound-mass : mass

So unless you specify which variant of the Foot-Pound-Second system, the term "pound" is ambiguous. Although in the U.S., "pound" in common usage is usually from the "British Gravitational (BG)" variant of Foot-Pound-Second, so "pound" would be weight. All of this Foot-Pound-Second ambiguity makes the Metric SI system look much simpler.

WEIGHT: In this video, the term "weight" is used multiple times. In older centuries, the term "weight" was the force on an object caused by gravity, but since Einstein's relativity theories, there has been academic discussions about whether "weight" only applies to gravity, or whether "weight" applies to any accelerated reference frame system. In pre-Einstein days, "weight" could be a scalar magnitude (single number without direction) because gravity was always toward the ground. But since Einstein's relativity with accelerated reference frames, then "weight" might need to be a vector value (direction included, which may require more than one number to indicate direction). Even now, textbooks defining "weight" differ on whether or not "weight" requires gravity, or whether "weight" is a scalar magnitude or a vector value. Therefore, in this video, "Weight" is technically an ambiguous term, but by common sense and common experience, we all know what is being talked about.

Lots of stuff and excitement, but the most important point dogded completely in your Space X enthusiasm - can they make the flip 100% safe for passengers? Answer - and we all know this - no. Even Falcon 9, with all its reliabilty, would never get certified to land with people on it.

So what's the point of Starship (as currently designed) if it can't land with people on it? Before it stands any chance of being certified to carry people, it will need to have buit in redundancies - if the main method of landing fails, a backup will still get you down. This will need a radical redesign - so radical that they may as well just go back to the drawing board and start again. Starship, as currently designed, may be very clever (and Space X ditto), but it will never be safe enough to land on Earth with people on it.

And, before people point out that aircraft, as incredibly safe as they are, still sometimes crash on landing - yes, they do, but so many aircaft fly so often, with so many people on them, that the actual percentage of passengers kiled per mile flown is miniscule. A Starship accident could easily kill more people than have died in total in the whole history of spaceflight - in one go.

Great video, Tim!
Because you defined TWR for your use in the video, this is probably just a pedantic comment, but hopefully interesting.
TWR in rocketry is sometimes something called “Thrust to Earth Weight Ratio”, which is slightly different than standard TWR. In short, it is the net force (thrust – weight) to weight ratio. What this does is make TWR represent the acceleration in multiples of g. So, 0.0 is “maintain velocity”, and -1.0 is “free fall”. I’m really not sure how widespread its use is other than if you see a lift-off TWR below 1, it’s obviously this thing. But this is why engineers define terms, even seemingly common ones, in their documentation.

28:10 - and that is why you cannot land Starship on earth using more than one Raptor without doing a suicide burn. Starship's current pre-landing mass exceeds the minimum thrust of 2 Raptors, so in that configuration the Thrust to Weight ratio always exceeds 1.

But SpaceX don't want to do a suicide burn if they can avoid it. Why is that? Because you need to to reduce speed to 0 kph at 0 m of altitude, but for the first landings on Mars YOU WON'T KNOW when 0 metres of altitude actually is until you are almost on the ground, as you need to find a suitable place to land "on the fly", and you do not know precisely in advance what relative altitude that place lies at. So, it's far better to have the capability to hover properly, or decelerate very slowly, while sideslipping to the chosen landing spot & computing its altitude.

You touched on the fact that landing on Mars requires only 38% of the thrust. The thrust to weight ratios are therefore very different: on Earth, a Raptor in its current configuration can, as you show, hover any mass of 880 kN up to 2,200 kN. On Mars that converts to 2,315 kN to 5,789 kN. And that's for a SINGLE Raptor, so on a single Raptor a Starship will need to carry extra pre-landing mass of 915 kN in the form of fuel &/or payload in order to do a proper hover-based landing. If a Starship carrying no payload has a pre-landing mass of 1,400 kN [as you give it here], you cannot land on Mars on two Raptors without carrying at least 3,230 kN of fuel &/or payload [because 2 Raptors cannot hover less than 4,630 kN], That's the equivalent of carrying a further 2.3 pre-landing mass Starships in fuel &/or payload.

THAT is why they are practising a proper hover landing on one Raptor on earth: it's because they will need to do it on Mars - at least to start with.

You blew the conversion of newton's to weight. Newton's are a measure of force not a weight. If you want to move a KG by 1 meter in one second in a vacuum in weightlessness you need 1 newton of push. If you have more newton's it takes less time, if you have less than a newton it will take longer. A kilogram weighs approximately 2.2 lbs, but it takes only .225 poundstone move that Kilogram of mass 1 meter. You can use footpounds or kgmeters or any unit of mass or weight and it only changes the time it takes to move that KG by 1 meter.

Could they not just fire a drogue chute or ribbon attached near the nose at maybe 1000AGL instead of relying on engine start/gimbal for the vertical pivot?  As soon as the chute is producing any drag, the pivot to vertical will begin and the fuel in the tanks will almost immediately settle and allow a subsequent engine relight for landing with far less risk of vapor ingestion.  A small chute or drag ribbon would add a (fairly) negligible amount of weight, and chute pyrotechnics are a very well understood and reliable technology.

Why is no one talking about just how great of an idea fans and a net is?  Allows the starship to guide itself into a massive updraft that then gently lowers the craft into a net for retrieval.  No fuel or relight required.  The best part is no part.

Velocities at 30:53 are clearly wrong. 1. Red case (300m). 4 s * g = 40m/s gravity loss. Which gives us terminal velocity smaller than 100m/s. 2. Orange case. 18s * g = 176 m/s. Even smaller terminal velocity.
Delta-v required for belly flop can be simply calculated as terminalVelocity + timeOfFlop*g [gravity drag] - integralOverAeadynamicDrag + loosInHorizontalPosition. The help of aerodynamic drag will be small (in vertical position cross-section is small, as explained by Tim), surly smaller than losses over the flop.

Okay, having gone through the entire video now, I am still left with the same worry as I was after your 'Starship doesn't have an abort system' video: any system like this with a lack of redundancy is scary. No redundancy is what killed the crew of the Challenger, it's what killed the crew of the Columbia (And Vladimir Komarov if you want to go back further). And you're completely right: the Raptor hasn't matured yet, and Starship isn't even close to passing the prototype stage, fair enough. But it's safe to say that by this point, that excuse no longer applies to the Falcon 9, and yet its most recent landing failure was only two months ago. A single point of failure on the center engine, and the booster went kaboom on re-entry. Excusable when it's just a booster, but when there are people on there that have no alternative, it's suddenly a big problem.

Great video Tim! Amazing to learn and understand just how much more fuel would be required to start the flip a little earlier. I was one of many wondering why they left it so late. But my main thinking for starting a little earlier was that it would give the fuel a couple more valuable seconds in which to settle in the tanks a bit better - thus hopefully minimising the chances of the engines getting a mouthful of gas, rather than liquid, which I think is something they are struggling with. So far we have had not enough pressure, too much gas in the lines, and maybe lastly SN11 which may have suffered from an over pressure event in one of the headers. All a very fine balancing act indeed.

Great video! The one question I still have is: During the development program, there should be plenty of extra delta-V, so why not splurge on flipping earlier? It should provide at least a little more safety.They seem not to care about losing a test articles, and I know they are making a new one like every 2 weeks, but that's still at least 2 weeks of potential testing lost.

At a very high level, Starship will come in like the space shuttle, belly first., but at the last possible minute, it will flip around putting untold forces on the people inside the rocket just so it can land upright.  Why not do what the shuttle did when Starship returns to earth?  What is wrong attempting to land on a runway.  Why not enhance this part of it to make it better and make turn around quicker?  There is less risk with no sloshing fuel to worry about exploding and we know the impact forces on humans  of gliding in instead of doing the flip. Great as always but it got me wanting to see the trade-offs between a winged runway landing second stage (or lifting body or both) and the powered landing. I've convinced myself that runway landing is better in terms of payload mass fraction. Dead stick landings are proven and require no propellant or sea level raptors which more than makes up for the weight of the wings and landing gear I'd wager. Oh yeah and the control surfaces don't need huge batteries like the Starship's. Of course; I also think that there should be "cruise ships" that stay in space for the trip and a Mars shuttle as a separate system and a surface to LEO system rather than a one size fits all vehicle.

SN10, at 120 tons, landed at around 10 m/s and was damaged in the process, later exploding partially resulting from said heavy landing. And it's more than twice as slow as the SRB touchdowns in the water.
